activitiesAndInterests.activityDescription: Mastercard ist ein internationales Technologieunternehmen im Zahlungsverkehr. Unser Ziel ist es, eine inklusive, digitale Wirtschaft voranzutreiben, von der alle Beteiligten weltweit profitieren. Deshalb sorgen wir dafür, dass Zahlungen sicher, einfach und smart abgewickelt und für jeden zugänglich gemacht werden. Unsere Innovationen und Lösungen basieren auf sicheren Daten und Netzwerken und helfen Einzelpersonen, Finanzinstituten, Regierungen und Unternehmen, die Bandbreite ihrer Möglichkeiten voll auszuschöpfen. Im Bereich der politischen Interessenvertretung stehen die Potentiale der Digitalisierung des  Zahlungsverkehrs, des Zugangs zu Finanzdistleistungen sowie die Nutzung von Datendiensten durch den Dialog zwischen dem Handel, den Verbrauchern, der Wirtschaft und der Politik im Vordergrund. Dazu nehmen wir an Veranstaltungen teil, fördern den Diskurs und fördern den Austausch anhand entsprechender Positionen. Wir kommunizieren regelmäßig mit Vertretern des Deutschen Bundestages und der Bundesregierung, um die Interessen von Mastercard  in Deutschland zu vertreten und zu fördern.

text.text:
Mastercard’s summary position on the proposal for a
regulation on the establishment of the digital euro
Mastercard welcomes the opportunity to share its views on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament
and of the Council on the establishment of the digital euro (the proposal). We believe the draft proposal is an
important step towards developing the basis of a public-private partnership to deliver public money for a new digital
age. However, the proposal gives rise to complex trade-offs that without substantive amendment, could distort
competition in a way that would bring unintended consequences in terms of market fragmentation, and reductions to
the resilience, rate of innovation, and diversity of options in the European payment landscape. Legislators are urged
to reconsider the provisions outlined below and utilize the benefits of an open competitive market to better
accommodate the needs of intermediaries, merchants and ultimately users of the digital euro.
Please find below an overview of Mastercard’s key remarks and recommendations:
Proposed compensation model risks harming competition
The digital euro compensation model is based on imposed limits and the provision of free basic services, where fees
charged for the digital euro can never exceed existing means of payment. However, the limits on fees do not consider the
potentially significant new implementation costs that merchants and payment service providers (PSPs) will incur to offer
these free basic services. Nor does it ensure a level playing field with other means of payment. If the proposal proceeds
with mandatory acceptance and intermediaries and merchants have no choice but to opt-in, then they must not be
constrained by regulated levels of compensation and should be given the choice to determine the most appropriate and
cost-effective way to recuperate the costs being imposed as well as deliver commercially viable solutions to their
customers.
Mastercard’s recommendation
1. Fees and charges for the digital euro should be based on recovery of all costs and margin
The commercial model for a digital euro must be sustainable and avoid public subsidies to ensure a level playing field
with all electronic means of payments. It should also be compliant with all applicable legislation, including anti-trust
laws. For these reasons, all costs, including implementation costs, recurring service costs, processing costs, and other
technology or infrastructure requirements, such as costs for implementing and operating the scheme and switch,
should at a minimum be recuperated. Further, merchant service charges should be set by the market, cover all costs
and apply an appropriate margin. Mastercard also considers that any inter-PSP fee should not exceed the higher of
a) all relevant costs incurred by payment services providers for its provision of digital euro payments, including a
reasonable margin of profit; and
b) fees or charges requested for comparable digital means of payment
April 2024
Enable open infrastructure and interoperability with existing payment mechanisms
Instead, the Eurosystem can ensure continued access to payments in central bank money through an open infrastructure
model (Figure 1). This means that alongside commercial bank money, the digital euro can be accessed, cleared and
processed using also existing rails. The Eurosystem remains operator of the settlement infrastructure. By leveraging
existing acceptance technologies, networks and solutions, as well as fostering interoperability in European payments, the
private sector can help support the Eurosystem to distribute a digital version of the euro and facilitate adoption. This
would promote it as another choice available to all consumers in support of the singleness of the currency, unify the user
experience and increase system resilience.
Mastercard’s recommendation
2. Enable distribution of the digital euro through open infrastructure and interoperability with existing
payment mechanisms to promote an integrated European payments market
The proposal should expressly state that interoperability be supported inter alia using open standards and by leveraging
existing payment infrastructures, networks and solutions for the purpose of accepting and processing digital euro
payment transactions, including that used by comparable digital means of payment. Where available, payment service
providers should be given the choice to use existing infrastructure for the acceptance and processing of transactions in
digital euro. Merchants should be required to display all payment options that are available.
The ECB’s expanded remit will cause an unlevel playing field
The proposed legislation will expand the ECB’s remit beyond simply issuing a digital version of cash and providing the
necessary regulatory framework for that instrument. Instead, the proposal envisions an expansion of the ECB’s operations
to replicate a variety of infrastructure and services currently provided by PSPs and intermediaries, without being subject
to the same rules and market conditions. At the same time, the ECB will determine pricing for intermediaries to distribute
the digital euro and remain a supervisor of systemically important payment systems and financial institutions who are
PSPs. Unlike the ECB’s monetary policy independence to maintain price stability, the ECB will be both supervisor of FMIs
as well as the provider of an explicitly consumer facing scheme that will be competing directly with supervised payment
infrastructure. This gives rise to a concerning conflict of interest, particularly if the regulations will expressly determine
The digital euro proposes the delivery of two policy objectives
– not one. The first is the issuance of the euro in digital form,
and the second is the creation of a new, publicly operated,
pan-European payment network. In attempting to bundle
the delivery of both objectives, the Eurosystem may
jeopardise its goal of making central bank money more
accessible, given the issuance of the digital euro is tied to the
rollout and investment in a new pan-European payment
network, with significant testing and implementation hurdles
to overcome. Requiring users to employ only one payment rail
for the digital euro would also create artificial barriers
between the euro and commercial bank money, fragmenting
the user payment experience and ultimately go against the
ambition of an integrated payment market.
Figure 1 – Open infrastructure for the Digital Euro
April 2024
competitive outcomes through regulated compensation models. This is not the case with T2 (formerly Target2), which
serves as the eurozone’s sole mechanism for inter-bank settlement in central bank money and is exclusively focused on
serving the needs of financial institutions (as well as the Eurosystem’s monetary policy operations).
Mastercard’s recommendation
3. The expansion of the ECB’s remit should be reassessed, or clear separation and independence between the
ECB’s role as digital euro scheme operator and market supervisor be imposed.
We call on legislators to consider how the expansion of the ECB’s remit for the provision of the digital euro respects
the principle enshrined in Article 127(1) TFEU of an open market economy with free competition and ensures a level
playing field. If the proposal proceeds as drafted and the ECB’s remit is significantly expanded, it is imperative that a
clear separation between the monetary, supervisory and payment systems oversight tasks of the ECB be established
in accordance with Articles 119-144, 219 and 282-284 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and
its activities in relation to the digital euro payment system.
Aligning the processing of personal data with GDPR
Mastercard agrees that data protection by design and by default should be embedded in the design of the digital euro
from the outset in order to guarantee a high level of privacy to its users. Privacy is a fundamental right and a precondition
for the successful implementation and uptake of the digital euro by both citizens and professionals. Giving users choice is
also critical to their adoption of the digital euro since users already have varying degrees of privacy preferences for existing
payment solutions and may be interested in accessing additional services. The existing EU data protection framework,
embodied in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR, Regulation 2016/679), provides a robust and comprehensive
safeguard for the privacy rights of EU citizens, establishing stringent rules for the collection, processing, and storage of
personal data. However, the current draft could be misinterpreted as preventing further personal data processing by PSPs
and providers of support services despite the lawfulness of the processing under the Article 6(1) GDPR, for example when
necessary for the performance of a contract, or to provide value-added services to their customers when their consent
has been given.
Mastercard’s recommendations
4. The digital euro proposal should fully adhere and align with the GDPR rules on personal data processing.
The legislation should be aligned with the GDPR without creating prescriptive restrictions on personal data use that
would go beyond existing privacy and data protection safeguards, ultimately reducing consumer choice and the ability
for businesses to offer innovative on top services. We therefore call on EU legislators to clarify the interplay of the
digital euro proposal with the GDPR and clearly spell out under Articles 34 and 36 that further personal data, beyond
the purposes outlined under these two articles, will be treated in accordance with Article 6(1) GDPR. This is aligned
with EDPS/EDPB Joint Opinion 02/2023.

text.text:
September 20, 2023
1
Mastercard’s recommendations on SCA and PSD3
Mastercard welcomes the European Commission’s draft legislative package on payments of June 2023,
which includes a proposal for a Payment Services Regulation (EU PSR) and a proposal for a Third Payment
Services Directive (PSD3).
Please find below Mastercard’s recommendations on the strong customer authentication (SCA) rules
contained in the proposal for a EU PSR and on other rules contained in the proposal for a PSD3.
Strong Customer Authentication (SCA)
Mastercard’s top recommendations
1. Liability of technical service providers and scheme operators. The EU PSR requires that technical
service providers and scheme operators are financially liable if SCA is not applied due to their fault. We
believe this requirement should be entirely removed because it is based on the misconception that
operators of payment schemes and technical service providers were late in the implementation of SCA.
In reality, the delays were caused primarily by thousands of merchants having to migrate to SCA and
hundreds of millions of consumers having to be enrolled in SCA-compliant solutions. In addition,
technical service providers and scheme operators are already subject to sufficient liability requirements
under their contractual arrangements and national civil and commercial law requirements. This
requirement would also disincentivize technical service providers, especially small SCA enablers, to
continue to provide their services because of the unlimited liability they would face.
2. Behavioral and environmental characteristics. We strongly welcome the new EU PSR requirement
that issuers shall take into account ‘environmental’ and ‘behavioral’ characteristics (e.g., user’s location,
transaction time, device used, spending habits, transaction history, session data and device IP) for their
transaction monitoring, particularly as the processing of this information is essential to prevent and
detect identity fraud to keep the payment system safe. We believe that merchants should be required
to send this information to the payer’s PSP. This environmental and behavioral information should
also be recognized as a valid authentication factor of ‘inherence’ (something the user is) if sufficiently
precise to authenticate the cardholder. Promoting the use of behavioral and environmental data for
authentication increases the accessibility and inclusivity of SCA designed for all.
3. GDPR and behavioral biometrics. We strongly welcome the new possibility envisaged under the EU
PSR for payment systems and PSPs to process special categories of personal data (e.g., biometric data)
without the need for the user’s express consent under Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR). We believe
that technical service providers should be expressly allowed to process these categories of personal
data without user’s consent to better align with market reality. This will protect the substantial public
September 20, 2023
2
interest of the well-functioning of the internal market and ensure the adoption of inherence-based SCA
technologies leveraging biometric data.
4. SCA delegation and outsourcing. We believe that the EU PSR should clarify that SCA delegation is
never ‘critical’ outsourcing and expressly allow multilateral or scalable outsourcing agreements for
SCA delegation to facilitate innovative and secure authentication solutions. We also believe that only
authentication models whereby the payer’s PSP is not in control of SCA should qualify as outsourcing.
Conversely, authentication models whereby the payer’s PSP is in control of SCA should not be
considered SCA delegation and should fall outside the outsourcing requirements.
5. Business continuity and resilience during technical outages. The EU PSR is silent on whether
transactions requiring SCA can continue to be authorized through the authorization network when the
authentication infrastructure is down. We believe that the need to ensure business continuity during
technical incidents should be addressed by the regulation. The EU PSR should therefore exceptionally
and temporarily allow payments without SCA during technical incidents affecting the authentication
infrastructure with appropriate safeguards to ensure the security of payments.
6. Fine-tuning SCA exemptions. The EU PSR requires that the EBA develops Regulatory Technical
Standards (RTS) inter alia on exemptions from SCA requirements. Our industry experience with SCA and
exemptions suggests that the current exemptions regime should be fine-tuned for greater efficiency,
user experience and balance. To this end, we suggest that further exemptions are envisaged for lowrisk
and low-value use cases such as alternative fuel filling, vending machines and donation terminals,
airline in-flight commerce, and corporate payment processes. We also propose to raise the cumulative
limit for the contactless exemption to EUR 250.
7. MIT and SEPA Direct Debits. We welcome the clarification provided by the EU PSR that SCA is not
required for transactions initiated ‘by the payee only’. However, we are of the view that an
unconditional (‘no question asked’) refund right should not apply to merchant-initiated transactions
(MIT) as this would significantly increase fraud and MIT already ensure a very high level of consumer
protection. In addition, the EU PSR requires SCA for the initial mandate only when it is given with the
involvement of the payer’s PSP. To increase security, we believe that SCA should be required for both
MIT and SEPA Direct Debits mandates regardless of whether the payer’s PSP is involved in the settingup
of the mandate. We also believe that SCA should never be required for amending mandates.
Additional Mastercard’s recommendations on SCA include the following:
Liability for gross negligence
We believe that regulation should expressly envisage further use cases and instances of gross negligence
where consumers should partially or entirely bear the responsibility.
September 20, 2023
3
Accessibility of SCA solutions
We welcome the new requirement to make SCA solutions accessible for vulnerable customers (e.g.,
elderly, people with disabilities, non-digitally savvy consumers). Nonetheless, we believe that PSPs should
be required to provide non-smartphone-based SCA solutions only to customers who do not have access
to app-based solutions. We also propose to increase the accessibility and inclusivity of SCA by promoting
the use of behavioral and environmental data for authentication. This would be very helpful for customers
who may have difficulties in remembering a password or typing an OTP.
Categories of SCA factors
We welcome the new EU PSR requirement that SCA factors can belong to the same category of
‘knowledge’ (i.e., something only the user knows), ‘possession’ (i.e., something only the user possesses)
and ‘inherence’ (i.e., something the user is). This opens the door to new and convenient combinations of
authentication factors. We however believe that SCA solutions based on the use of two knowledge
factors (e.g., two passwords) should not be allowed as they are not sufficiently secure. Conversely, two
possession factors should be allowed, provided their independence is sufficiently preserved through the
use of different devices.
Third Payment Services Directive (PSD3)
Mastercard’s recommendations on PSD3 are the following:
Access to payment systems and interplay with SFD
We strongly welcome the new requirement introduced by the PSD3 to allow Payment Institutions (PIs)
and E-money Institutions (EMIs) to directly participate in payment systems that are designated under the
Settlement Finality Directive (SFD).
Licensing of Payment Institutions
The PSD3 includes a new requirement for existing PIs and EMIs to seek a new authorization as PIs under
the PSD3. Member States can provide mechanisms to automatically grant this new authorization to
existing PIs and EMIs. We believe that existing PIs and EMIs should be allowed to continue to provide
their services under their current PSD2/EMD2 licenses without the need to seek a new PSD3 license.
This is important to ensure business continuity of existing PIs and EMIs and avoid regulatory arbitrage. If
the requirement to seek a new authorization were to be maintained, we believe that the PSD3 should at
least (1) indicate that the existing PIs and EMIs are allowed to provide their services until a final decision
on their re-authorization is taken by their competent authorities and (2) foresee a winding down period of
at least 6 months if a competent authority decides to withdraw their authorization.
September 20, 2023
4
Surcharging
We believe that surcharging should always be allowed for payment cards of ‘three-party’ schemes that
are not subject to the interchange fee caps under Regulation (EU) 2015/751. Allowing surcharge for these
payment instruments would ensure that merchants can recover the extra costs for accepting those
instruments.
Limited network exclusion and hybrid cards
Regulation should allow the existence of ‘hybrid’ payment instruments that accommodate an open-loop
and a closed-loop functionality. Hybrid payment instruments are innovative products that already exist
in the market and provide real consumer and merchant value.
Buy Now Pay Later
We welcome the clarification that ‘Buy Now Pay Later’ (BNPL) services are not a payment service under
the PSD3. We believe that, for the sake of clarity, the PSD3 should expressly indicate that entities
providing BNPL services are nonetheless subject to the PSD3 requirements if they provide payment
services in combination with such BNPL services.
Definition of ‘technical service providers’
We believe that the definitions of ‘technical service provider’ under the EU PSR and PSD3 should be
aligned for greater clarity.
Mastercard looks forward to contribu[ng to the discussions and engaging with all EU policymakers as
the proposal goes through the legisla[ve process.

text.text:
November 2023 Mastercard Impulspapier
Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen und staatlicher Unterstützung über Bezahlkarten
Europa und insbesondere Deutschland stehen in den letzten Jahren vor einer beispiellosen
Herausforderung: Ein enormer Zustrom von Schutzbedürftigen hat viele Kommunen, Verwaltungen
und das Sozialsystem an Grenzen gebracht. Oftmals wird auch von einer Überlastung gesprochen. Vor
diesem Hintergrund besteht ein dringendes Bedürfnis nach effizienten und sicheren Lösungen, die die
öffentliche Verwaltung prozessual entlasten, die Kosten für die Gesellschaft reduzieren und den Einsatz
der Mittel sachgerecht sicherstellen.
Hierzu zählt auch die Verteilung von finanziellen Zuwendungen für Schutzbedürftige. Erprobte und auf
internationalen Standards basierende Zahlungstechnologien stellen eine einfache und schnell
umzusetzende Lösung dar. Diese Technologien werden bereits in vielen europäischen Ländern sowie
durch internationale Organisationen eingesetzt. Sie unterstützen so auch finanzielle Inklusion und
Digitalisierung, wie von der Weltbank1 adressiert.
Sogenannte Bezahlkarten weisen vielfältige Vorteile gegenüber anderen Mechanismen, wie
beispielsweise Barzahlungen oder Gutscheine, auf. Konkret lässt sich mit diesem Instrument die
ordnungspolitische Steuerung sehr fein justieren, auch auf lokaler Ebene. Zugleich sind Bezahlkarten
effizient in der Umsetzung und somit gesellschaftlich ressourcenschonend. Ebenso wird ein
diskriminierungsfreier Zugang zu Sozialleistungen ermöglicht.
Vorteile der Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen über Bezahlkarten (Debit- und Prepaidkarten)
1. Einfache und schnelle Implementierung: Durch den Einsatz von auf internationalen Standards
basierenden Bezahlkarten in digitaler oder physischer Form können Sozialleistungen effizient in
großem Umfang in kurzer Zeit distributiert werden. Aufwändige und risikoreiche Bargeldlogistik
oder das Verteilen von Gegenständen des täglichen Bedarfs entfallen.
2. Keine Notwendigkeit für neue Infrastruktur: Ein auf Bezahlkarten basierendes Programm zur
Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen kann auf Basis von existierender technischer Infrastruktur
implementiert werden. Kartenausgebende Unternehmen (z.B. Banken und Sparkassen) können
hierfür auf bereits etablierte Standardprozesse zurückzugreifen.
3. Flexible Konfigurationsmöglichkeiten: Bezahlkarten können individuell, entsprechend den
Präferenzen von Bund und Ländern, konfiguriert werden. Dies gilt für Anwendungsfälle wie
Bargeldabhebungen, e-Commerce, Einsatz im In- und Ausland oder in PLZ-Gebieten sowie für
den Einsatz bei bestimmten Händlergruppen. Die Funktionalitäten können ohne eine Neu-
Ausgabe der Karte laufend adjustiert werden.
4. Kosteneffizienz: Die Verwendung von Karten reduziert Kosten für die Verwaltung und führt zu
einer besseren Klimabilanz im Vergleich zur Verteilung von Bargeld, da die teure und unter
Nachhaltigkeitsaspekten nicht optimale Notwendigkeit des Druckens, Transports und der
1 Committee on Payments and Market Infrastructure, World Bank Group, Payment Aspects of Financial Inclusion; World Bank Document
November 2023 Mastercard Impulspapier
Verteilung vermieden wird. Eine Studie der Bundesbank2 zeigt, dass die Gesamtkosten für
Bargeldtransaktionen höher sind als die für Kartenzahlungen.
5. Einfachheit in der Anwendung: Die breite Akzeptanz von Karten sichert Zugang zu allen
notwendigen Waren und Dienstleistungen, die im Wege der Sozialleistungen bezogen werden
können. Eine schnelle Sperrung und Ersatz bei Verlust oder Diebstahl ist jederzeit möglich.
Karten mit moderner Chip- und PIN-Technologie bieten zusätzliche Sicherheitsschichten. Der
Support bei Fragen zum Einsatz und bei Problemen erfolgt durch die jeweiligen
Partnerunternehmen (z.B. Banken und Sparkassen).
6. Inklusion: Karten ermöglichen es den Nutzer:innen, so wie jede/r andere Karteninhaber:in zu
bezahlen. Dies vermeidet das Stigma, welches beispielsweise mit Gutscheinen verbunden ist.
Der Einsatz von Karten kann zudem einen besseren Zugang zur digitalen Wirtschaft
ermöglichen. Ein Sachverhalt auf den auch die Weltbank in einer Studie3 hinweist.
Mastercard als Netwerk-Partner für die technische Infrastruktur
Die Nutzung von Bezahlkarten bietet viele Vorteile für Kommunen, Verwaltungen und die
Schutzsuchenden selbst. Sie ist effizient, schnell umsetzbar, flexibel und frei von Diskriminierung. Die
Erfahrungen von Mastercard mit diesem Anwendungsfall in verschiedenen Ländern und in
Zusammenarbeit mit Regierungen und internationalen Organisationen4 ermöglichen es, diese Vorteile
optimal zu nutzen. Dabei stellt die Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen an Asyl- und Schutzsuchende
lediglich einen Anwendungsfall für Bezahlkarten dar. Ebenso kann dieses Instrument für die schnelle
und unbürokratische Auszahlung von anderen staatlichen Leistungen und Soforthilfen bei
Katastrophen genutzt werden.
Bei weiteren Fragen:
Dr. Peter Robejsek
Geschäftsführer Mastercard Deutschland
Peter.Robejsek@mastercard.com
Über Mastercard:Mastercard ist ein globales Technologieunternehmen im Zahlungsverkehr. Unser Ziel ist es, eine inklusive, digitale Wirtschaft
voranzutreiben, von der alle profitieren und in der immer und überall sichere, einfache und smarte Zahlungen durchgeführt werden können.
Mit sicheren Daten und Netzwerken, starken Partnerschaften und Leidenschaft helfen unsere innovativen Produkte und Lösungen
Einzelpersonen, Finanzinstituten, Regierungen und Unternehmen, ihr volles Potenzial auszuschöpfen – in mehr als 210 Ländern und Territorien.
Mastercard ist unter der Registernummer R002253 im Lobbyregister für die Interessenvertretung gegenüber dem Deutschen Bundestag und
der Bundesregierung eingetragen und akzeptiert den Verhaltenskodex für Interessenvertreterinnen und Interessenvertreter.
2 Kosten der Bargeldzahlung im Einzelhandel (bundesbank.de): Die Gesamtkosten der Zahlungsverfahren belaufen sich auf insgesamt 5.432 Millionen Euro pro
Jahr für den deutschen Einzelhandel. Davon entfallen rund 3.775 Millionen Euro auf Barzahlungen, während kartengestützte Zahlungen insgesamt nur etwa
1.657 Millionen Euro pro Jahr kosten.
3 Committee on Payments and Market Infrastructure, World Bank Group, Payment Aspects of Financial Inclusion; World Bank Document
4 Programme und Projekte wurden bereits in Ländern wie Rumänien, Frankreich und UK sowie mit dem World Food Programme des UNHCR umgesetzt.

text.text:
Mastercard’s summary position on the proposal for a
regulation on the establishment of the digital euro
Mastercard welcomes the opportunity to share its views on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament
and of the Council on the establishment of the digital euro (the proposal). We believe the draft proposal is an
important step towards developing the basis of a public-private partnership to deliver public money for a new digital
age. However, the proposal gives rise to complex trade-offs that without substantive amendment, could distort
competition in a way that would bring unintended consequences in terms of market fragmentation, and reductions to
the resilience, rate of innovation, and diversity of options in the European payment landscape. Legislators are urged
to reconsider the provisions outlined below and utilize the benefits of an open competitive market to better
accommodate the needs of intermediaries, merchants and ultimately users of the digital euro.
Please find below an overview of Mastercard’s key remarks and recommendations:
Proposed compensation model risks harming competition
The digital euro compensation model is based on imposed limits and the provision of free basic services, where fees
charged for the digital euro can never exceed existing means of payment. However, the limits on fees do not consider the
potentially significant new implementation costs that merchants and payment service providers (PSPs) will incur to offer
these free basic services. Nor does it ensure a level playing field with other means of payment. If the proposal proceeds
with mandatory acceptance and intermediaries and merchants have no choice but to opt-in, then they must not be
constrained by regulated levels of compensation and should be given the choice to determine the most appropriate and
cost-effective way to recuperate the costs being imposed as well as deliver commercially viable solutions to their
customers.
Mastercard’s recommendation
1. Fees and charges for the digital euro should be based on recovery of all costs and margin
The commercial model for a digital euro must be sustainable and avoid public subsidies to ensure a level playing field
with all electronic means of payments. It should also be compliant with all applicable legislation, including anti-trust
laws. For these reasons, all costs, including implementation costs, recurring service costs, processing costs, and other
technology or infrastructure requirements, such as costs for implementing and operating the scheme and switch,
should at a minimum be recuperated. Further, merchant service charges should be set by the market, cover all costs
and apply an appropriate margin. Mastercard also considers that any inter-PSP fee should not exceed the higher of
a) all relevant costs incurred by payment services providers for its provision of digital euro payments, including a
reasonable margin of profit; and
b) fees or charges requested for comparable digital means of payment
April 2024
Enable open infrastructure and interoperability with existing payment mechanisms
Instead, the Eurosystem can ensure continued access to payments in central bank money through an open infrastructure
model (Figure 1). This means that alongside commercial bank money, the digital euro can be accessed, cleared and
processed using also existing rails. The Eurosystem remains operator of the settlement infrastructure. By leveraging
existing acceptance technologies, networks and solutions, as well as fostering interoperability in European payments, the
private sector can help support the Eurosystem to distribute a digital version of the euro and facilitate adoption. This
would promote it as another choice available to all consumers in support of the singleness of the currency, unify the user
experience and increase system resilience.
Mastercard’s recommendation
2. Enable distribution of the digital euro through open infrastructure and interoperability with existing
payment mechanisms to promote an integrated European payments market
The proposal should expressly state that interoperability be supported inter alia using open standards and by leveraging
existing payment infrastructures, networks and solutions for the purpose of accepting and processing digital euro
payment transactions, including that used by comparable digital means of payment. Where available, payment service
providers should be given the choice to use existing infrastructure for the acceptance and processing of transactions in
digital euro. Merchants should be required to display all payment options that are available.
The ECB’s expanded remit will cause an unlevel playing field
The proposed legislation will expand the ECB’s remit beyond simply issuing a digital version of cash and providing the
necessary regulatory framework for that instrument. Instead, the proposal envisions an expansion of the ECB’s operations
to replicate a variety of infrastructure and services currently provided by PSPs and intermediaries, without being subject
to the same rules and market conditions. At the same time, the ECB will determine pricing for intermediaries to distribute
the digital euro and remain a supervisor of systemically important payment systems and financial institutions who are
PSPs. Unlike the ECB’s monetary policy independence to maintain price stability, the ECB will be both supervisor of FMIs
as well as the provider of an explicitly consumer facing scheme that will be competing directly with supervised payment
infrastructure. This gives rise to a concerning conflict of interest, particularly if the regulations will expressly determine
The digital euro proposes the delivery of two policy objectives
– not one. The first is the issuance of the euro in digital form,
and the second is the creation of a new, publicly operated,
pan-European payment network. In attempting to bundle
the delivery of both objectives, the Eurosystem may
jeopardise its goal of making central bank money more
accessible, given the issuance of the digital euro is tied to the
rollout and investment in a new pan-European payment
network, with significant testing and implementation hurdles
to overcome. Requiring users to employ only one payment rail
for the digital euro would also create artificial barriers
between the euro and commercial bank money, fragmenting
the user payment experience and ultimately go against the
ambition of an integrated payment market.
Figure 1 – Open infrastructure for the Digital Euro
April 2024
competitive outcomes through regulated compensation models. This is not the case with T2 (formerly Target2), which
serves as the eurozone’s sole mechanism for inter-bank settlement in central bank money and is exclusively focused on
serving the needs of financial institutions (as well as the Eurosystem’s monetary policy operations).
Mastercard’s recommendation
3. The expansion of the ECB’s remit should be reassessed, or clear separation and independence between the
ECB’s role as digital euro scheme operator and market supervisor be imposed.
We call on legislators to consider how the expansion of the ECB’s remit for the provision of the digital euro respects
the principle enshrined in Article 127(1) TFEU of an open market economy with free competition and ensures a level
playing field. If the proposal proceeds as drafted and the ECB’s remit is significantly expanded, it is imperative that a
clear separation between the monetary, supervisory and payment systems oversight tasks of the ECB be established
in accordance with Articles 119-144, 219 and 282-284 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and
its activities in relation to the digital euro payment system.
Aligning the processing of personal data with GDPR
Mastercard agrees that data protection by design and by default should be embedded in the design of the digital euro
from the outset in order to guarantee a high level of privacy to its users. Privacy is a fundamental right and a precondition
for the successful implementation and uptake of the digital euro by both citizens and professionals. Giving users choice is
also critical to their adoption of the digital euro since users already have varying degrees of privacy preferences for existing
payment solutions and may be interested in accessing additional services. The existing EU data protection framework,
embodied in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR, Regulation 2016/679), provides a robust and comprehensive
safeguard for the privacy rights of EU citizens, establishing stringent rules for the collection, processing, and storage of
personal data. However, the current draft could be misinterpreted as preventing further personal data processing by PSPs
and providers of support services despite the lawfulness of the processing under the Article 6(1) GDPR, for example when
necessary for the performance of a contract, or to provide value-added services to their customers when their consent
has been given.
Mastercard’s recommendations
4. The digital euro proposal should fully adhere and align with the GDPR rules on personal data processing.
The legislation should be aligned with the GDPR without creating prescriptive restrictions on personal data use that
would go beyond existing privacy and data protection safeguards, ultimately reducing consumer choice and the ability
for businesses to offer innovative on top services. We therefore call on EU legislators to clarify the interplay of the
digital euro proposal with the GDPR and clearly spell out under Articles 34 and 36 that further personal data, beyond
the purposes outlined under these two articles, will be treated in accordance with Article 6(1) GDPR. This is aligned
with EDPS/EDPB Joint Opinion 02/2023.

text.text:
September 20, 2023
1
Mastercard’s recommendations on SCA and PSD3
Mastercard welcomes the European Commission’s draft legislative package on payments of June 2023,
which includes a proposal for a Payment Services Regulation (EU PSR) and a proposal for a Third Payment
Services Directive (PSD3).
Please find below Mastercard’s recommendations on the strong customer authentication (SCA) rules
contained in the proposal for a EU PSR and on other rules contained in the proposal for a PSD3.
Strong Customer Authentication (SCA)
Mastercard’s top recommendations
1. Liability of technical service providers and scheme operators. The EU PSR requires that technical
service providers and scheme operators are financially liable if SCA is not applied due to their fault. We
believe this requirement should be entirely removed because it is based on the misconception that
operators of payment schemes and technical service providers were late in the implementation of SCA.
In reality, the delays were caused primarily by thousands of merchants having to migrate to SCA and
hundreds of millions of consumers having to be enrolled in SCA-compliant solutions. In addition,
technical service providers and scheme operators are already subject to sufficient liability requirements
under their contractual arrangements and national civil and commercial law requirements. This
requirement would also disincentivize technical service providers, especially small SCA enablers, to
continue to provide their services because of the unlimited liability they would face.
2. Behavioral and environmental characteristics. We strongly welcome the new EU PSR requirement
that issuers shall take into account ‘environmental’ and ‘behavioral’ characteristics (e.g., user’s location,
transaction time, device used, spending habits, transaction history, session data and device IP) for their
transaction monitoring, particularly as the processing of this information is essential to prevent and
detect identity fraud to keep the payment system safe. We believe that merchants should be required
to send this information to the payer’s PSP. This environmental and behavioral information should
also be recognized as a valid authentication factor of ‘inherence’ (something the user is) if sufficiently
precise to authenticate the cardholder. Promoting the use of behavioral and environmental data for
authentication increases the accessibility and inclusivity of SCA designed for all.
3. GDPR and behavioral biometrics. We strongly welcome the new possibility envisaged under the EU
PSR for payment systems and PSPs to process special categories of personal data (e.g., biometric data)
without the need for the user’s express consent under Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR). We believe
that technical service providers should be expressly allowed to process these categories of personal
data without user’s consent to better align with market reality. This will protect the substantial public
September 20, 2023
2
interest of the well-functioning of the internal market and ensure the adoption of inherence-based SCA
technologies leveraging biometric data.
4. SCA delegation and outsourcing. We believe that the EU PSR should clarify that SCA delegation is
never ‘critical’ outsourcing and expressly allow multilateral or scalable outsourcing agreements for
SCA delegation to facilitate innovative and secure authentication solutions. We also believe that only
authentication models whereby the payer’s PSP is not in control of SCA should qualify as outsourcing.
Conversely, authentication models whereby the payer’s PSP is in control of SCA should not be
considered SCA delegation and should fall outside the outsourcing requirements.
5. Business continuity and resilience during technical outages. The EU PSR is silent on whether
transactions requiring SCA can continue to be authorized through the authorization network when the
authentication infrastructure is down. We believe that the need to ensure business continuity during
technical incidents should be addressed by the regulation. The EU PSR should therefore exceptionally
and temporarily allow payments without SCA during technical incidents affecting the authentication
infrastructure with appropriate safeguards to ensure the security of payments.
6. Fine-tuning SCA exemptions. The EU PSR requires that the EBA develops Regulatory Technical
Standards (RTS) inter alia on exemptions from SCA requirements. Our industry experience with SCA and
exemptions suggests that the current exemptions regime should be fine-tuned for greater efficiency,
user experience and balance. To this end, we suggest that further exemptions are envisaged for lowrisk
and low-value use cases such as alternative fuel filling, vending machines and donation terminals,
airline in-flight commerce, and corporate payment processes. We also propose to raise the cumulative
limit for the contactless exemption to EUR 250.
7. MIT and SEPA Direct Debits. We welcome the clarification provided by the EU PSR that SCA is not
required for transactions initiated ‘by the payee only’. However, we are of the view that an
unconditional (‘no question asked’) refund right should not apply to merchant-initiated transactions
(MIT) as this would significantly increase fraud and MIT already ensure a very high level of consumer
protection. In addition, the EU PSR requires SCA for the initial mandate only when it is given with the
involvement of the payer’s PSP. To increase security, we believe that SCA should be required for both
MIT and SEPA Direct Debits mandates regardless of whether the payer’s PSP is involved in the settingup
of the mandate. We also believe that SCA should never be required for amending mandates.
Additional Mastercard’s recommendations on SCA include the following:
Liability for gross negligence
We believe that regulation should expressly envisage further use cases and instances of gross negligence
where consumers should partially or entirely bear the responsibility.
September 20, 2023
3
Accessibility of SCA solutions
We welcome the new requirement to make SCA solutions accessible for vulnerable customers (e.g.,
elderly, people with disabilities, non-digitally savvy consumers). Nonetheless, we believe that PSPs should
be required to provide non-smartphone-based SCA solutions only to customers who do not have access
to app-based solutions. We also propose to increase the accessibility and inclusivity of SCA by promoting
the use of behavioral and environmental data for authentication. This would be very helpful for customers
who may have difficulties in remembering a password or typing an OTP.
Categories of SCA factors
We welcome the new EU PSR requirement that SCA factors can belong to the same category of
‘knowledge’ (i.e., something only the user knows), ‘possession’ (i.e., something only the user possesses)
and ‘inherence’ (i.e., something the user is). This opens the door to new and convenient combinations of
authentication factors. We however believe that SCA solutions based on the use of two knowledge
factors (e.g., two passwords) should not be allowed as they are not sufficiently secure. Conversely, two
possession factors should be allowed, provided their independence is sufficiently preserved through the
use of different devices.
Third Payment Services Directive (PSD3)
Mastercard’s recommendations on PSD3 are the following:
Access to payment systems and interplay with SFD
We strongly welcome the new requirement introduced by the PSD3 to allow Payment Institutions (PIs)
and E-money Institutions (EMIs) to directly participate in payment systems that are designated under the
Settlement Finality Directive (SFD).
Licensing of Payment Institutions
The PSD3 includes a new requirement for existing PIs and EMIs to seek a new authorization as PIs under
the PSD3. Member States can provide mechanisms to automatically grant this new authorization to
existing PIs and EMIs. We believe that existing PIs and EMIs should be allowed to continue to provide
their services under their current PSD2/EMD2 licenses without the need to seek a new PSD3 license.
This is important to ensure business continuity of existing PIs and EMIs and avoid regulatory arbitrage. If
the requirement to seek a new authorization were to be maintained, we believe that the PSD3 should at
least (1) indicate that the existing PIs and EMIs are allowed to provide their services until a final decision
on their re-authorization is taken by their competent authorities and (2) foresee a winding down period of
at least 6 months if a competent authority decides to withdraw their authorization.
September 20, 2023
4
Surcharging
We believe that surcharging should always be allowed for payment cards of ‘three-party’ schemes that
are not subject to the interchange fee caps under Regulation (EU) 2015/751. Allowing surcharge for these
payment instruments would ensure that merchants can recover the extra costs for accepting those
instruments.
Limited network exclusion and hybrid cards
Regulation should allow the existence of ‘hybrid’ payment instruments that accommodate an open-loop
and a closed-loop functionality. Hybrid payment instruments are innovative products that already exist
in the market and provide real consumer and merchant value.
Buy Now Pay Later
We welcome the clarification that ‘Buy Now Pay Later’ (BNPL) services are not a payment service under
the PSD3. We believe that, for the sake of clarity, the PSD3 should expressly indicate that entities
providing BNPL services are nonetheless subject to the PSD3 requirements if they provide payment
services in combination with such BNPL services.
Definition of ‘technical service providers’
We believe that the definitions of ‘technical service provider’ under the EU PSR and PSD3 should be
aligned for greater clarity.
Mastercard looks forward to contribu[ng to the discussions and engaging with all EU policymakers as
the proposal goes through the legisla[ve process.

text.text:
November 2023 Mastercard Impulspapier
Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen und staatlicher Unterstützung über Bezahlkarten
Europa und insbesondere Deutschland stehen in den letzten Jahren vor einer beispiellosen
Herausforderung: Ein enormer Zustrom von Schutzbedürftigen hat viele Kommunen, Verwaltungen
und das Sozialsystem an Grenzen gebracht. Oftmals wird auch von einer Überlastung gesprochen. Vor
diesem Hintergrund besteht ein dringendes Bedürfnis nach effizienten und sicheren Lösungen, die die
öffentliche Verwaltung prozessual entlasten, die Kosten für die Gesellschaft reduzieren und den Einsatz
der Mittel sachgerecht sicherstellen.
Hierzu zählt auch die Verteilung von finanziellen Zuwendungen für Schutzbedürftige. Erprobte und auf
internationalen Standards basierende Zahlungstechnologien stellen eine einfache und schnell
umzusetzende Lösung dar. Diese Technologien werden bereits in vielen europäischen Ländern sowie
durch internationale Organisationen eingesetzt. Sie unterstützen so auch finanzielle Inklusion und
Digitalisierung, wie von der Weltbank1 adressiert.
Sogenannte Bezahlkarten weisen vielfältige Vorteile gegenüber anderen Mechanismen, wie
beispielsweise Barzahlungen oder Gutscheine, auf. Konkret lässt sich mit diesem Instrument die
ordnungspolitische Steuerung sehr fein justieren, auch auf lokaler Ebene. Zugleich sind Bezahlkarten
effizient in der Umsetzung und somit gesellschaftlich ressourcenschonend. Ebenso wird ein
diskriminierungsfreier Zugang zu Sozialleistungen ermöglicht.
Vorteile der Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen über Bezahlkarten (Debit- und Prepaidkarten)
1. Einfache und schnelle Implementierung: Durch den Einsatz von auf internationalen Standards
basierenden Bezahlkarten in digitaler oder physischer Form können Sozialleistungen effizient in
großem Umfang in kurzer Zeit distributiert werden. Aufwändige und risikoreiche Bargeldlogistik
oder das Verteilen von Gegenständen des täglichen Bedarfs entfallen.
2. Keine Notwendigkeit für neue Infrastruktur: Ein auf Bezahlkarten basierendes Programm zur
Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen kann auf Basis von existierender technischer Infrastruktur
implementiert werden. Kartenausgebende Unternehmen (z.B. Banken und Sparkassen) können
hierfür auf bereits etablierte Standardprozesse zurückzugreifen.
3. Flexible Konfigurationsmöglichkeiten: Bezahlkarten können individuell, entsprechend den
Präferenzen von Bund und Ländern, konfiguriert werden. Dies gilt für Anwendungsfälle wie
Bargeldabhebungen, e-Commerce, Einsatz im In- und Ausland oder in PLZ-Gebieten sowie für
den Einsatz bei bestimmten Händlergruppen. Die Funktionalitäten können ohne eine Neu-
Ausgabe der Karte laufend adjustiert werden.
4. Kosteneffizienz: Die Verwendung von Karten reduziert Kosten für die Verwaltung und führt zu
einer besseren Klimabilanz im Vergleich zur Verteilung von Bargeld, da die teure und unter
Nachhaltigkeitsaspekten nicht optimale Notwendigkeit des Druckens, Transports und der
1 Committee on Payments and Market Infrastructure, World Bank Group, Payment Aspects of Financial Inclusion; World Bank Document
November 2023 Mastercard Impulspapier
Verteilung vermieden wird. Eine Studie der Bundesbank2 zeigt, dass die Gesamtkosten für
Bargeldtransaktionen höher sind als die für Kartenzahlungen.
5. Einfachheit in der Anwendung: Die breite Akzeptanz von Karten sichert Zugang zu allen
notwendigen Waren und Dienstleistungen, die im Wege der Sozialleistungen bezogen werden
können. Eine schnelle Sperrung und Ersatz bei Verlust oder Diebstahl ist jederzeit möglich.
Karten mit moderner Chip- und PIN-Technologie bieten zusätzliche Sicherheitsschichten. Der
Support bei Fragen zum Einsatz und bei Problemen erfolgt durch die jeweiligen
Partnerunternehmen (z.B. Banken und Sparkassen).
6. Inklusion: Karten ermöglichen es den Nutzer:innen, so wie jede/r andere Karteninhaber:in zu
bezahlen. Dies vermeidet das Stigma, welches beispielsweise mit Gutscheinen verbunden ist.
Der Einsatz von Karten kann zudem einen besseren Zugang zur digitalen Wirtschaft
ermöglichen. Ein Sachverhalt auf den auch die Weltbank in einer Studie3 hinweist.
Mastercard als Netwerk-Partner für die technische Infrastruktur
Die Nutzung von Bezahlkarten bietet viele Vorteile für Kommunen, Verwaltungen und die
Schutzsuchenden selbst. Sie ist effizient, schnell umsetzbar, flexibel und frei von Diskriminierung. Die
Erfahrungen von Mastercard mit diesem Anwendungsfall in verschiedenen Ländern und in
Zusammenarbeit mit Regierungen und internationalen Organisationen4 ermöglichen es, diese Vorteile
optimal zu nutzen. Dabei stellt die Auszahlung von Sozialleistungen an Asyl- und Schutzsuchende
lediglich einen Anwendungsfall für Bezahlkarten dar. Ebenso kann dieses Instrument für die schnelle
und unbürokratische Auszahlung von anderen staatlichen Leistungen und Soforthilfen bei
Katastrophen genutzt werden.
Bei weiteren Fragen:
Dr. Peter Robejsek
Geschäftsführer Mastercard Deutschland
Peter.Robejsek@mastercard.com
Über Mastercard:Mastercard ist ein globales Technologieunternehmen im Zahlungsverkehr. Unser Ziel ist es, eine inklusive, digitale Wirtschaft
voranzutreiben, von der alle profitieren und in der immer und überall sichere, einfache und smarte Zahlungen durchgeführt werden können.
Mit sicheren Daten und Netzwerken, starken Partnerschaften und Leidenschaft helfen unsere innovativen Produkte und Lösungen
Einzelpersonen, Finanzinstituten, Regierungen und Unternehmen, ihr volles Potenzial auszuschöpfen – in mehr als 210 Ländern und Territorien.
Mastercard ist unter der Registernummer R002253 im Lobbyregister für die Interessenvertretung gegenüber dem Deutschen Bundestag und
der Bundesregierung eingetragen und akzeptiert den Verhaltenskodex für Interessenvertreterinnen und Interessenvertreter.
2 Kosten der Bargeldzahlung im Einzelhandel (bundesbank.de): Die Gesamtkosten der Zahlungsverfahren belaufen sich auf insgesamt 5.432 Millionen Euro pro
Jahr für den deutschen Einzelhandel. Davon entfallen rund 3.775 Millionen Euro auf Barzahlungen, während kartengestützte Zahlungen insgesamt nur etwa
1.657 Millionen Euro pro Jahr kosten.
3 Committee on Payments and Market Infrastructure, World Bank Group, Payment Aspects of Financial Inclusion; World Bank Document
